author: Morgan Housel
summary: Bubbles form when investors take cues from others playing a different game. A day trader and a retirement saver have completely different rational prices for the same stock. Beware of taking financial cues from people with different time horizons.
key_takeaways: Different investors have different games - what's rational for one may be crazy for another.
Bubbles form when long-term investors take cues from short-term traders.
Identify what game you're playing and ignore players of different games.

questions.question: Why can the same stock have a 'rational' price of both $5 and $500 depending on the investor?

options.text: Because stock valuation is entirely subjective
Because investors have different time horizons and goals
Because some investors are smarter than others

questions.explanation: A day trader just needs the stock to move in their direction by lunchtime. A retirement saver needs to analyze 30 years of cash flows. The factors they pay attention to are completely different.

questions.question: How do financial bubbles ACTUALLY form?

options.text: When everyone becomes greedy at the same time
When momentum attracts short-term traders who then set prices that long-term investors follow
When the government prints too much money
When companies lie about their earnings

questions.explanation: Bubbles form when the momentum of short-term returns attracts enough money that the makeup of investors shifts from mostly long term to mostly short term. Long-term investors then take cues from short-term traders playing a different game.

questions.question: What is the BIGGEST mistake long-term investors make during market bubbles?

options.text: Not selling their stocks quickly enough
Taking price cues from short-term traders who are playing a completely different game

questions.explanation: Bubbles do their damage when long-term investors start taking cues from short-term traders. A price that makes sense for a day trader is nonsense for a retirement investor, but the long-term investor thinks 'maybe they know something I don't.'
